thread.title: It gets scary: Ange defiant thanks to track record
thread.title_full: It gets scary: Ange defiant thanks to track record

title: It gets scary: Ange defiant thanks to track record
text:
Socceroos v United Arab Emirates: Ange Postecoglou, Mile Jedinak front the media Ben McKay, AAP, FOX SPORTS March 27, 2017 3:32pm 
AS crunch time in Australia’s World Cup qualifying effort looms, Ange Postecoglou is laughing off the rising pressure on his team. 
Four straight draws leading into Tuesday night’s meeting with United Arab Emirates makes the Allianz Stadium clash a must-win match if the Socceroos are to stay on track to win a place in Russia next year. 
Australia are three points behind group B leaders Japan and Saudi Arabia, who occupy the two automatic qualification places. 
In the most recent of those draws, a lacklustre 1-1 result against Iraq last Thursday, Postecoglou unveiled a new ultra-attacking formation with just three defenders. 
That restructure combined with the team’s winless run has brought criticism and anxiety that Australia might miss the World Cup for the first time since 2002. As ever, Postecoglou remains defiant. 
“For 20 years in coaching what I’ve been consistent in producing is teams that win things,” he said. 
“I do it in a certain way. It does get scary. I understand that. 
“I’m glad people care and I’m glad people are talking about it. I’m glad people are nervous and anxious and I’m glad they’re passionate. 
“I’ll cop it a bit but we’ll see it through. (The pressure) doesn’t faze me.” 
Against UAE, Australia will be without playmakers Tom Rogic and Aaron Mooy due to injury and suspension. 
James Troisi, who impressed in a 10-minute cameo against Iraq, could start in Mooy’s place, with Nathan Burns another option. 
Tomi Juric appears likely to maintain his position leading the line, despite clamour for veteran Tim Cahill to return to the fore. 
Regular centre-back Trent Sainsbury is favoured to come into defence, with Brad Smith another possible starter. 
Whatever the starting line-up, captain Mile Jedinak said the most important thing was to regain the ascendancy in physical contests after being out-muscled against Iraq. 
“It didn’t look the best and we don’t like that,” he said. 
“It happened. We allowed them too much time. 
“I was disappointed as much as anybody after that. 
“But you’ve got to realise what’s at stake. These countries don’t always get opportunities to qualify for World Cups.” Postecoglou said he wanted to win and win in style against the Emirati, continuing his campaign to turn Australia into a force to be reckoned with. “We all want to qualify but we’re determined on continuing this path to be a certain type of team. All of us are behind it. The players embrace it,” he said. “It was always going to come down to these last few games, especially at home. “It’s still in our hands. We don’t deviate or cower now just because people are anxious about qualifying. 
“We’re not doing this so we don’t qualify. We’re doing it so we qualify and hopefully make an impact.” 
Watch the Socceroos host United Arab Emirates on Tuesday on Fox Sports 505 HD. Preview 7pm, kick-off 8pm AEDT.
